reviewText:
I've had a few attempts playing this game, let me summarise:

At launch:  a buggy mess, a festival of bugs and crashes and AI/UI issues.  You could not place certain (crucial) structures like steps .. which would allow you to mount archers on the walls.  Archers did not return fire as mace-men approached your walls.  It was a ridiculous and frustrating mess.  Only positive I can say is I liked some of the gritty art style.

A few months later:  it seemed like the developer was as disappointed as most consumers .. there was apparently some advices saying they blamed the publisher who pushed for an early release, and that they would endeavour to give consumers the game that they deserve through patching and constant and consistent after-sale improvements.  (Apparently the game we deserve is 'poo poo' because even with them working through the list of problems, the game, although playable in some ways, was still deeply flawed.  Archers still wouldnt retaliate, still had issues placing simple things like stairs up to walls).

About a year after launch:  I decide to give the game one last try.  (Loved earlier Stronghold titles and the concept in general).  They made some improvements to the game .. archers could fire back .. structures could be placed .. overall the game became somewhat playable .. BUT .. even after all that work they really barely achieve 'passable' .. archers may retaliate, but there's no mechanic for wall cover, and they get no elevation bonus to range or accuracy .. so basically 20 archers attacking a wall v 20 archers on a wall .. probably the attackers would win because they are clustered into one big kill-group, firing all their arrows together accurately, while the wall guys are scattered about and some would be out of range to attack... but yeah, basically the ones on the wall get no benefit).  Also you'll place units on a wall and they will become un-movable.  Just plain stuck.

So basically, despite a good legacy and concept, the game sucks.

Bad pathfinding and bugs, glitches, and hell knows what else beyond comprehension plague this game. I have gotten hours of enjoyment out of it, but that was only because I am a die-hard stronghold fan. Anything less will find no enjoyment in this game, only the frustration of trying to get not everything, but ANYthing at all to work the way you want it to. There are only 2 solid points to this game - the graphics and the gridless building system, both of which are the best in the series as of the time of this review. The military units don't behave properly and have minimal AI on their own...there IS no AI for enemy opponents whatsoever, meaning more often than not they sit there doing ♥♥♥♥all until you go to them instead, there are massive game-breaking glitches with the physics and pathfinding, and the multiplayer servers are so god awful that they had to slap a 150 troop limit and 125 building limit (INCLUDING TOWERS AND GATEHOUSES) into the multiplayer to make it barebones functional and you can still expect massive lag left and right - not computer lag, but network lag where the whole game will slow to a crawl.

Want the bonuses of a 3D stronghold game that doesn't suck and has functional multiplayer? Go get crusader 2.

Otherwise just get ANY game in the series besides this one. This is the ONLY game in the entire series that I would not recommend, as it is the only one that provides more frustration than it does fun - the next worst in the series falls to Stronghold Legends, which is not nearly as bad as this and is easily playable and enjoyable.

-If you are a Stronghold fan, do NOT buy this game. The frustration is painful and not worth it.-

I have always been a Stronghold fan and wouldn't hesitate to recommend Stronghold, Stronghold 2, Stronghold Crusader or even Stronghold Legends to any of my friends. So of course I was biding my time until the game finally released and squandered $60 on it. I'd equate the anticipation level of buying it and actual gameplay akin to Duke Nukem Forever.

While there certainly are positives: the game is gorgeous when rendered and boasts a lot of new content. The basics that make the game flow and playable are the worst in the series. As much as I would like to rant as to how Firefly could botch a release so badly after having released a prior version, Stronghold Crusader Extreme, wherein the player could field an army of up to 10,000 troops and limitless buildings, I have no idea.

The number 1 issue that ruined the game for me was the slow replenishment of the player's campfire (distributable population) mixed with the prioritzation of industry over military. For instance if an opposing army kills the workers of any industry buildings beyond your walls, or even wolves for that matter, you will not be able to build any troops until the workers are replenished in the order that they were killed. Unfortunately that is just one glitch of many that should have been cleaned up during simple game testing.

Whoever was in charge of cleaning up this game ought to have used Lemon Pledge.

reviewText:
Stronghold 3 may look like a medieval fortress simulator where feudal armies throw themselves against vast layers of fortifications with thick walls and towers that look as if they reach the skies. This is unfortunately only true if you play one of the scenarios that feature already constructed fortifications. Throughout the rest of the game you will never get to build anything more than a few haphazardly placed walls and the occasional watch tower.

The problem with Stronghold 3 is it's speed. Everything moves at a dreadfully slow pace. Gathering resources and building structures seem to take forever and most of the game seems to take place without any interaction from you, simply waiting for something to happen. The extremely tiny maps doesn't help either, making every town feel cramped.

You play as a feudal lord starting every map with your, very small, castle and some starting peasants. As you build resource gathering structures or conscript soldiers those peasants get used up and to attract more you need to provide them with adequate housing, food and not as much plague as you would like to inflict upon the lazy ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s.

As your town grows you start to get involved in the more costly resources as well as the more complicated resource chains letting you equip your army better and feed your populace more sufficiently. Along the way and depending on the scenario or campaign mission you're on you might face the additional threat of invading armies or super aggressive wolves that'll kill your poor defenseless peasants and put a stop to production until you can attract some more.

The problem with economic and city-building aspects of the game is as mentioned before, the speed. Everything happens at a snail's pace. You place your initial resource gathering buildings, got get a cup of coffee, come back and place the another resource gather. You repeat this process until you get enough of an income to start placing the more advanced resource harvesters as well as building the beginnings of an army and then you go get a cup of coffee and come back when you've got enough resources to place another advanced harvester or recruit another soldier. You spend more time waiting than actually playing the game and that is a serious design flaw.

I am normally all for slow paced intelligent games but this is just ridiculous and the slow speed adds nothing to the game's depth.

The military aspects of the game is predictably simple. You harvest resources to construct weapons and then use those weapons to conscript your peasants into military service as a variety of different types of soldiers. The actual combat however pretty much boils down to box selecting your army and clicking attack on the enemy army, hoping you got the right numbers and combination of troops.

Graphically there is nothing wrong with the game but not much right either. It neither adds nor detracts much from the experience. The sounds are comfortably boring although the soundtrack does feature some neat flute music that fits the genre very nicely.

All in all Stronghold suffers from two serious design flaws that takes it from being a great idea to a bad game. The slow speed makes the game boring and any sense of accomplishment you get from finally getting a proper economy working is instantly removed when a new map starts and you are thrown back to square one having to rebuild. The lack of proper fortress building however is what truly kills it for me. You will never come to a point in the game where building those mighty fortifications that is the game's trademark becomes natural. It takes far too long to get there and once you do you could probably have won the map three times over.

Stick to the older titles in the series or looks elsewhere, this is not a game that delivers what it promised.

reviewText:
I took a chance with my four dollars plus change and got it.  Glad I did.  In spite of all the hate that has been heaped on this game, it has a certain appeal.  That is, if you like town/castle building, hoarding resources, ordering peasants around, and seeing your enemies crushed and driven before you; while listening to the lamentation of their women.

Soundtrack is fitting for a feudal lord, but John Barley Corn tends to play a tad too often, and the lyrics remind me of brave Sir Robin.  Graphically, the landscapes are rendered like impressionistic oil paintings, which is fitting for this genre, although not for this time period.  Also, if you've got a hankering for medieval architecture, you'll be treated to variety of historically accurate building styles; a few have given me ideas for building defenses in other games like 7 Days to Die.

The one thorn in my crown over this game is multi-player because I can never connect.  However, for the sale price the single player modes are worth it, and real feudal lords didn't have an internet for their multi-player games either.  I give it two forks up!  (Note: One of the forks is somewhat bent from jamming it in my ethernet port while trying to get multi-player to work.)

reviewText:
Grade 4/10
Stronghold series has been in deep trouble and continues to do so. That is very sad thing, because I really liked the original stronghold games. Buy either original Stronghold or Stronghold Crusader or wait and hope that the Stronghold Crusader 2 will be better.

Full review:
The developers of Stronghold 3 said that they attempted to return back to the roots of original Stronghold games after that Stronghold 2 and Stronghold Legends had been disappointments. Personally I don't see that much resemblance between original Stronghold games and Stronghold 3. This might not have been the problem, because this series might require refreshing instead of going back to roots. Whatever the developers tried to do, the game is a failure. This result was heavily affected by the fact that the publisher pushed the game to markets before it was ready. Now the game doesn't have any game braking bugs anymore but some annoying bugs still exist and the gameplay just isn't nearly as good as it should be.

I'll start with the gameplay. The gamplay is too slow. The gameplay in the actual Stronghold games has always been slower than in the Crusader versions to place more value on the economy but in this game the gameplay is just too slow. The units are too slow and also the economy is also extremely slow. Even new citizens spawn too slowly. The result of this is that the army sizes are extremely low as well as the size of the castle.

Next i'll talk more specifically about the economy. The economy in this game seems to be very difficult to manage. It seems like that no matter the player does, the player is all the time on the edge of collapse of the economy even if the enemies don't attack you castle. Even worse is how popularity is calculated. Before this game the popularity was very stable once the most basic needs of the citisens were secured. In Stronghold Crusader 3 however the popularity changes all the time because
a) the economy is all the time on the edge of collapse
b) amount of population has drastic effect on popularity
c) Popularity is always going up or down unlike in previous game in which it was easy to have stable popularity.

The result of both economy and popularity being at the edge of collapse is that the player uses almost all the time micromanaging these things leaving no time to build the defenses or care about the army in a game in which half of the game should be doing these two things.

Third main problem in this game is the castle building. The building of walls and towers was changed dramatically for this game, but unfortunately the new system is total disaster. It is difficult to use and some of the difficulty might actually be caused by bugs. In a game, where economy is requiring your constant micromanaging and enemies attack every now and then a difficult to use waal bulding system is huge problem. The new system also prevents the creation of imaginative castles. On top of this the player is unable to create moats around his castle inexcept in the scenario builder. The developers have admitted their mistake and the building of walls and towers will be reverted to how it was before for Stronghold Crusader 2.

Fourth main problem is the combat. The combat is very slow and units under melee attack are very unresponsive. This makes makes usage of fast troops pointless. In previous games I preferred to have mixed army (because different units had their own strenghts), but in this game only useful troops are swordmen and crossbowmen. Exception being knights that are needed to destroy siege engines.

To summarise the gameplay part: Stronghold crusader is a game combining medieval combat, castle building and economy and it fails in all these aspects.

Last thing that I would like to mention are graphics. The graphics of this game are awful. Both the soldiers and buildings are are very difficult to distinguish from each other and I also dislike the chosen artistic style. If the developers of this game can't create clear and beutiful 3D objects they should revert back to 2.5D graphics that was used in original stronhold game because that game had very beautiful and clear graphics.

reviewText:
While Stronghold 3 is the worst received entry into the franchise to date, don't let the negative reviews stop you from picking it up for under $5 on sale and enjoying the second chapter of a story started over 10 years previous with the original Stronghold.

I personally find the game frustrating and enjoyable in equal parts, yes, there are bugs in the game which can make you want to pull your hair out at times, the difficulty of some missions is not for the faint of heart and on some level appeals to the inner masochist.

This is a game you must play for yourself to truly appreciate the ambitions never fully realized due to it's broken state at release, cry the beloved castle.

The Good:
+ The price, on sale I got it for less than $5
+ The graphics, I personally love the weathered impressionist atmosphere of the game world
+ The single player campaigns by themselves are lengthy enough to keep you occupied for a dozen hours or more
+ Includes map editor for you to create your own eyecandy scenarios or MP skirmish maps
+ The removal of the grid means building placement looks more natural, good for those who love eyecandy
+ Great flexibility in designing the medieval castle of your dreams

The Bad:
- The dynamic castle design (post grid) was never fully completed and you'll have units getting stuck in the walls which is annoying as hell
- The story is told through the use of hand drawn illustrations, if they had been full color the presentation would have been superb. As is, the black and white charcoal smudges feel somewhat unfinished.
- The leaderboard for mission scores is offline with little likelihood of being restored
- Peasants can get stuck in buildings
- Killing pits are all but invisible, good luck deleting them if you want to put another building in your minefield.
- The game is prone to unpredictable crashes, sometimes when you are creating a game save.

After experiencing first hand the problems with this game I can understand why players who bought this game full price are still seething. That said, I do recommend picking this game up on sale if you've played and enjoyed Stronghold 2 or even if only to understand why the release was such a disaster.

reviewText:
I really hoped that this Stronghold would be more like the good old Stronghold games (Stronghold / Stronghold Crusader) but I got disappointed. I bought the game after they said that the worst bugs got fixed. Yea sure..


Negative Points
Bugs
- Horrible, game breaking bugs (for example troops get stuck in walls or just dont walk, killed all enemy troops and I still dont win in siege mode etc).
- Game crashs very often.

AI/Troops
- The AI is buggy and ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥. Sometimes my troops just ignore enemy troops even if they are in attack range, sometimes my troops ignore my commands, the AI or my own troops use the farthest way to the target even if the short way is clearly in front of them, especially in siege mode the AI act foolish.
- The controlling of troops works bad. It is difficult to select 1 unit in your army, controlling your army just dont feel good at all. Often I cant even command my troops to a point because they just stop several meters in front or after the point (pretty bad if you want to coordinate an attack).

Skirmish mode
- No skirmish mode in this Stronghold. Seriously? This alone is reason enough to not buy the game!

Campaign
- Poorly told with black/white pictures.. I lost the interest in the story very quickly.
- I could only finished the economic campaign because game crashed frequently..

Gameplay
- The castle building sucks (that's a big problem because this is a game about BUILDING CASTLES). I dont have enough space for a big, good looking and working castle. ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t!
-The game speed is so slow, it takes sooo long to get an army and a working economy because new people come very slowly and work slowly. The troops walk slowly too, everything is just slow!
- The building limit is 125 building and 300 troops by default. You can change it when you edit the game files but you will get major lag even if your pc is good.
- The mechanism for placing buildings is smooth and works surprisely good - but on the other hand placing a wall is pure pain.

Multiplayer
- Couldnt finish a single game because the game always crashed.
- Different modes are avalible but I coudlnt test them.
- MP is dead. Suprise suprise..



Neutral Points
Graphics
- The graphics is not good and not bad. Many people say that the graphics of Stronghold 3 is too bad bad I think it is acceptable for a Stronghold game.



Positive Points
Map editor
- Game got a level editor. I didnt work much with it but it seems ok



ConclusionIf you fit in one of the following groups you should NOT buy this game:
Stronghold game series fan
Fan of castle building games
People who like medieval game
Strategy games fans
Well, all other people shouldnt buy the game too..

Still, same thing was happening in Crusader 1 and Stronghold 1 as well, with exception that in Crusader 1 this unit would disappear, or remain stuck on wall crenelation until the player does something to set him free.

Also, many complain how they cannot play with massive armies in multiplayer... Why do we need to play with so many troops? Can we play with smaller troops? We would make some smaller castles, and attack each other earlier with less troops... In the end - it is the same if me and my opponent have 50, or 500 troops. Still, I must admit that I wasn't playing it in multiplayer much, and those games I started - I did face the lag, but I cannot say I have some powerful computer, so I do assume that is the reason why I had those problems. For this reason I decided to play only multiplayer games 1v1 on smaller maps, but it doesn't have to do much with the game itself - it's because of my PC... Also, I hope that we should be able to play multiplayer games with less troops and less buildings, and still, to have the fun. :) In fact, that is another challenge! Try to make your economy efficient as much as possible with less buildings. :)

The other thing about Stronghold 3 is the fact that I was reading some reviews before buying Stronghold 3, and I knew there wouldn't be skirmish, and I knew there are still those bugs - so I got the game with low expectations. :) So, when I got the game, I was only looking at those good things of the game, and still, there are more good parts, and those bad ones.

Nevertheless, it is not an excuse, and I am also sad that Firefly gave up this game, and that they didn't work on it a little more to fix those few remaining bugs.

I would also like to add that it is Stronghold 3 in which Firefly introduced some new interesting things such as: building walls in all possible directions, and putting any buildings wherever I want and rotate it however I want; special abilities of some troops, such as men at arms: they made spearmen more useful this way, etc... Also, I like it more how a castle looks in Stronghold 3 than how it looks in other Stronghold games - here castles are more natural, but that is only a matter of taste I guess.

Among those new stuff I do dislike how they made troops just leave the barracks - peasants do not need to walk to the barracks... This is something that could be exploited even in some campaign missions! I also dislike how they made the siege camps just like in Stronghold 2. One doesn't need to bring the engineers (and to protect them from the enemy) to construct mass of catapults in the middle of nowhere.

I only want to say that besides its bad reputation Stronghold 3 is not that bad as they say - it is a good game, and we do have to admit that with this game Firefly gave us something new! I am sure that if the game wasn't published too early, they would have done it way better.
1. there would be less things to be fixed in patches, and
2. Stronghold fans wouldn't be so much driven away from the game after their first impressions, although it is bad that Stronghold 3 doesn't offer skirmish mode. (I guess that they had though/hoped it would be as good to us as Stronghold 1 was without skirmish mode, but in year 2011 we were expecting nothing less that a game with skirmish mode.)

Sadly, that bad reputation Stronghold 3 got was almost certainly the reason why they gave up Stronghold 3, and why they left some more things to be fixed... Even if they made a perfect game afterwards, little people would get it. Little people would be playing it, there wouldn't be much of those who would recommend it to someone, little people would be buying it...

Still, even though I am recommending this game, my advice would be: don't get this game with high expectations, and still, you should have fun playing it. :) Also, I don't think it is worth 27,99€ - don't rush when buying it, you should be able to find a retail version for less, or you could wait from some sale at Steam, and to get it for less money.

Do you know what my advisor said to me the other day? “Sire, it looks like Stronghold 2, smells like Stronghold 2, tastes like Stronghold 2… Good thing we didn’t pay retail.”

I do love the Stronghold series, but Stronghold 3 is simply an abysmal failure.
In terms of game play, aesthetics and overall feel, I get the impression that someone just took Stronghold 2 and Stronghold Legends, put it in a blender and hit puree. That could have been a tasty beverage, but someone got the bright idea to strain out all of the detailed play mechanics and structures from Stronghold 2 and throw them away. Why?!

Stronghold 2 was an awesome game, BECAUSE you had so many management options and detailed buildings! There were geese and eels in a pond, which was my personal favorite structure, followed closely by the royal treasury. There were lots of detailed buttons and menus when you clicked on structures…

And while we’re on the subject, since everything in Stronghold 3 feels repurposed, what was so hard about carrying over all of the peasant dialog from the other games in the series!?! What fun is it to be lord of the castle if you can’t click on your peasants and listen to their simple babble? How are criminals supposed to steal from my granary if there ARE NO criminals!? Done away with gong pits? Madness I tell you!

All of that is gone in Stronghold 3… But at least there’s a day / night slider and some weather options in free build… Oh, and you can free rotate buildings… But the walls don’t connect to my castle anymore either… Win some, lose allot? As we’ve heard so many times before: “People are leaving the castle.”

reviewText:
It's sad as I was really looking forward to this game, but it's just not fun to play, and it was ruined simply due to a few major factors that killed the game for me (note that I only play RTSs in singleplayer).

The first problem that is it SHOULD have built upon Stronghold 2, which was an excellent game that was killed by a handful of crippling flaws (random crippling gong/rat disasters, resources were too demanding for basic units, and bad mission/campaign structures and progression. Instead this time they overcautiously regressed to Stronghold 1, but kept a lot of SH2 flaws and included a bunch of new ones.

The engine is actually less advanced than its predecessor in many ways that hurts the gameplay. Firstly, it is very buggy: dying enemies spawn giant triangles that block the screen, and in one mission my keep was invisible.
The interface is horrible- unlike the previous games that allowed very simple, versatile and accurate structure placement, this version seems incomplete- placing structures is clumsy, fiddly and difficult, walls are much harder to place OR connect (especially to structures that are supposed to back onto them like the Barracks), and the AI is awful, where the player often loses control for extended periods by sending units onto battlements. Combat is also a pain to organize

The multi-storey defenses are GONE with plain Strong-hold 1 structures returning (a pity). Yet the gameplay elements that turned Stronghold 2 from excellent to downright bad ARE STILL HERE. Random unpreventable disasters are back (which at least are more managable and less crippling than last time- except for the bears that spawn inside my castle and wipe out my farms). The awful campaign/mission structure in the previous game is back, with annoying and frustrating missions like escorting VERY slow units around, with the first proper defensive mission not occurring until the FOURTH LEVEL (the first mission archers are available too- before then you get your peasants to charge the enemy). Also, while the goofy characters and dialogue from Stronghold 2 are gone, there is simply no characters or dialogue at all- you get a few still-frame comics with a narrated monologue voiceover (by the Wolf and the two heroes only) at the start and end of each mission, and that's it.  One very good positive over the last game however is that lower units like archers no longer require Honour (which was a good idea- but should have only applied to top-level units to make them harder to spam).

Overall it's a huge pity, as Firefly had a lot to work with by their previous games, and could have very easily made an excellent game. Instead it feels rushed and incomplete, with far less sophistication than the previous game, and worse, little evidence that the team did much engine testing or gameplay testing before shipping it out.
I do genuinely hope they give it another shot, because they DO have the capability to make their next game amazing.

reviewText:
It's sad as I was really looking forward to this game, but it's just not fun to play, and it was ruined simply due to a few major factors that killed the game for me (note that I only play RTSs in singleplayer).

The first problem that is it SHOULD have built upon Stronghold 2, which was an excellent game that was killed by a handful of crippling flaws (random crippling gong/rat disasters, resources were too demanding for basic units, and bad mission/campaign structures and progression. Instead this time they overcautiously regressed to Stronghold 1, but kept a lot of SH2 flaws and included a bunch of new ones.

The engine is actually less advanced than its predecessor in many ways that hurts the gameplay. Firstly, it is very buggy: dying enemies spawn giant triangles that block the screen, and in one mission my keep was invisible.
The interface is horrible- unlike the previous games that allowed very simple, versatile and accurate structure placement, this version seems incomplete- placing structures is clumsy, fiddly and difficult, walls are much harder to place OR connect (especially to structures that are supposed to back onto them like the Barracks), and the AI is awful, where the player often loses control for extended periods by sending units onto battlements. Combat is also a pain to organize

The multi-storey defenses are GONE with plain Strong-hold 1 structures returning (a pity). Yet the gameplay elements that turned Stronghold 2 from excellent to downright bad ARE STILL HERE. Random unpreventable disasters are back (which at least are more managable and less crippling than last time- except for the bears that spawn inside my castle and wipe out my farms). The awful campaign/mission structure in the previous game is back, with annoying and frustrating missions like escorting VERY slow units around, with the first proper defensive mission not occurring until the FOURTH LEVEL (the first mission archers are available too- before then you get your peasants to charge the enemy). Also, while the goofy characters and dialogue from Stronghold 2 are gone, there is simply no characters or dialogue at all- you get a few still-frame comics with a narrated monologue voiceover (by the Wolf and the two heroes only) at the start and end of each mission, and that's it.  One very good positive over the last game however is that lower units like archers no longer require Honour (which was a good idea- but should have only applied to top-level units to make them harder to spam).

Overall it's a huge pity, as Firefly had a lot to work with by their previous games, and could have very easily made an excellent game. Instead it feels rushed and incomplete, with far less sophistication than the previous game, and worse, little evidence that the team did much engine testing or gameplay testing before shipping it out.
I do genuinely hope they give it another shot, because they DO have the capability to make their next game amazing.

reviewText:
I’m giving a “thumbs up” to SH3 because, despite its flaws, it retains the spirit of its predecessors and I actually had fun playing it.

It helps that you can pick it up cheap and they’ve patched it so I personally didn’t experience any major crashes or bugs. Ok, the odd unit did get stuck in a wall but that never ruined the fun.

I found the overall gameplay fine and had no problems with the UI or the economy or the building.  Having played all the older ones this one seems largely similar, which also includes the bad bits, and certainly does things no better.

My biggest gripe, that I have to mention, would be the lack of a skirmish mode.  This really limits the amount of time I’ve played it and for a castle building game the story line had too few opportunities to build a skirmish-mode-like castle.

So as a fan of the series, yes this incarnation was disappointing and limited, but I’d still recommend it when it appears in the sale, just to get a fix of castle building.

reviewText:
The story is simple, the bad guys have returned in their classic overly zealous kill everything and team up approach as we've seen in other Stronghold games, but this time... well actually this time it's exactly the same as before. You begin with nothing but a small settlement and meaningless objectives and gradually progress across the medieval world growing in strength and defeating progressively strong foes. The story is very linear and there is no tutorial, guess work is what keeps the game a challenge to begin with.

I'd really like to say it's a great game having been a fan of the series for years but I honestly wish I hadn't played it. The lack of tutorial or direction for the game frustrated me and despite the odd humorous comment by my adviser, I quickly grew bored. I can't recommend the game but if you do decide to buy it and can get your head around the unexplained and complicated economic system, you could get a good few hours of play from the game. While the previous games appealed to younger audiences, this game is simply too difficult without a tutorial for anyone too young.

Pros:
•	A lighthearted take on a grisly medieval world.
•	Amusing characters.
•	Wide range of units and buildings.
•	A fairly complex economic system.
Cons:
•	A linear storyline.
•	Lack of tutorial.
•	No real advances since Stronghold 2.
•	Essentially the same story as the previous 2 games.

reviewText:
The story is simple, the bad guys have returned in their classic overly zealous kill everything and team up approach as we've seen in other Stronghold games, but this time... well actually this time it's exactly the same as before. You begin with nothing but a small settlement and meaningless objectives and gradually progress across the medieval world growing in strength and defeating progressively strong foes. The story is very linear and there is no tutorial, guess work is what keeps the game a challenge to begin with.

I'd really like to say it's a great game having been a fan of the series for years but I honestly wish I hadn't played it. The lack of tutorial or direction for the game frustrated me and despite the odd humorous comment by my adviser, I quickly grew bored. I can't recommend the game but if you do decide to buy it and can get your head around the unexplained and complicated economic system, you could get a good few hours of play from the game. While the previous games appealed to younger audiences, this game is simply too difficult without a tutorial for anyone too young.

Pros:
•	A lighthearted take on a grisly medieval world.
•	Amusing characters.
•	Wide range of units and buildings.
•	A fairly complex economic system.
Cons:
•	A linear storyline.
•	Lack of tutorial.
•	No real advances since Stronghold 2.
•	Essentially the same story as the previous 2 games.

reviewText:
The story is simple, the bad guys have returned in their classic overly zealous kill everything and team up approach as we've seen in other Stronghold games, but this time... well actually this time it's exactly the same as before. You begin with nothing but a small settlement and meaningless objectives and gradually progress across the medieval world growing in strength and defeating progressively strong foes. The story is very linear and there is no tutorial, guess work is what keeps the game a challenge to begin with.

I'd really like to say it's a great game having been a fan of the series for years but I honestly wish I hadn't played it. The lack of tutorial or direction for the game frustrated me and despite the odd humorous comment by my adviser, I quickly grew bored. I can't recommend the game but if you do decide to buy it and can get your head around the unexplained and complicated economic system, you could get a good few hours of play from the game. While the previous games appealed to younger audiences, this game is simply too difficult without a tutorial for anyone too young.

Pros:
•	A lighthearted take on a grisly medieval world.
•	Amusing characters.
•	Wide range of units and buildings.
•	A fairly complex economic system.
Cons:
•	A linear storyline.
•	Lack of tutorial.
•	No real advances since Stronghold 2.
•	Essentially the same story as the previous 2 games.

reviewText:
Mac (IOX)
I wanted to like this game, I really did. As a avid stronghold fan I was looking forward to it. I had expected something like stronghold two's castel system and stronghold crusaders level of combat difficulty. I got a watered down buggy unfinished product. I'm not sure if they even play tested this thing.

One simple expample of its shortcoming is the compleat removal of any type of Player VS AI deathmatch game type, so all those stratagies that ou thought you may like but didnt want to try against human opponents? yea too bad. They also cut out custom senerios as it was called in crusader or user maps as it was called in two, entierly. This used to be one of my favorit parts of these games, being able to just go at it in compleatly customaisable enviorments. Well I guess that was jsut too much for this game.

Some of the smaller yet equally annoying things are the loss of the gong and rat mechanics, this is supposed to be compisated for by a large increase of the random events however I ahve no control over wether or not rats eat half my food now, instead of before where I was held somewhat accontable. Additionaly we lost the whole crime mechanic from two, so now if you ahve criminals you had best not punish them or else you will take a hit to the painfully fickel popularity meter.

They also cut out much of the difficulty I as able to beat the war and ecconomic campains without ever having to redo a level.... on the hardest difficulty. Firstly since when do we have difficultys in a Stronghold game? one of the best things was that ti forced you to put your best food forward and guided you throught the process of knowing squat about how to run a castel to being albe to take on 4 wolfs at a time (wolf the lord not the animal) secondly while I am what I would call a compitant player, I should not have been able to get through two of the three campains with no deaths on my first runthrough.

Overall buggy and far to easy, 4/10.

reviewText:
If you are a stronghold series fan I strongly recommend you stay as far away from this title as you possibly can.

I could start with the fact that graphics are unpolished, often times are stretched over meshes obscenely, or straight out glitch on a regular basis but that wouldn't do the terrifying experience that is stronghold 3 justice.

Perhaps I could mention the incredibly dull economic campaign, which has you essentialy gathering the same resources throughout all the missions with very little in the way of interaction once your infastructure is set up. Or perhaps I might mention the completely dead plot throughout the millitary campaign with nothing to be said for it minus that it is voice narrated inbetween missions?

Rather, I think I might mention that the game itself is just filled to the brim with glitches, looking like it was rushed to meet a release date, and then abandoned before it was ever fixed. For examplle, unit pathing is AWFUL. Units will frequently get stuck on completely flat terrain, corners, slight grades such as ramps and stairs, etc. And god forbid you attempt to play online. Just trying to successfully connect and join a game is a game in and of itself.

If you truely are a direhard stronghold fan and have the money to waste then you can check it out but consider yourself warned.
